awd_titl_txt: Transitioning Secondary to Tertiary Educators' Mathematical Knowledge for Teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates the significance of Mathematical Knowledge for Teaching (MKT) in an understudied population of instructors who fall between traditional divisions of high school and college teaching. Past research has typically assumed that an instructor is either a high school or college instructor, but not both. Degree and certification programs also make this assumption. However, many educators teach both secondary (high school) and tertiary (college) classes throughout the course of their careers, sometimes simultaneously. This project highlights educators in the secondary-to-tertiary (S2T) transition with implications for teaching practices in both settings. 
 
The goals of this project are to study and better support these S2T math educators by using ideas of MKT. MKT includes various domains of math educator knowledge such as knowledge of math content, connections between topics across courses, and knowledge of students, teaching, and curriculum. In phase one, a qualitative study will compare and contrast the priorities of individuals who have expertise in both secondary and tertiary education. In phase two, the expert perspectives will be embedded in a capstone course for a master’s degree program targeting S2T educators. A second round of data collection and analysis will explore the possible impacts on teacher knowledge for the target population.   This project initiates a research trajectory that can inform the math education community about the S2T transition for educators, part-time and dual-enrollment faculty, community college instructors, teacher education, distance or online education, and adult education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Typically, high school teachers and college instructors are thought to be separate individuals with completely different career trajectories. In fact, the pathways to become a high school teacher versus a college instructor are dissimilar. However, there are many math educators who have experience teaching in both high schools and colleges. In some cases, educators acquire additional credentials and make a career move from one type of school to the other. In other cases, educators teach at both types of schools simultaneously. For example, some are full-time high school teachers who also work as part-time college faculty during the summers or evenings. Additionally, some teach dual-enrollment classes, which are courses that count for both high school and college credit at the same time.

In this two-year study, the research team investigated the perspectives and self-reported teaching practices of math educators with experience in both high schools and colleges. As far as the research team knows, this is the first study that focused on these educators in between institutional boundaries. The study utilized an online survey with open-ended questions. Overall, participants reported that they were deeply interested in students’ interests and future career aspirations. They also reported that they were aware of best practices in teaching.

In the first phase of the project, the study focused on having these educators compare and contrast their high school and college teaching. One pattern that the research team observed was that many instructors commented about limits of their decision-making or lack of autonomy. Some of this wasn’t surprising as high schools have a standard curriculum. However, a higher number of instructors reported a lack of decision-making in the college setting than expected. Another pattern was that teachers were significantly influenced by time pressure in colleges. Several discussed how challenging it was to cover the required content when college classroom instructional time was so limited, to the point that some chose to avoid using evidence-based pedagogical methods (e.g., types of active learning). Perhaps because of this time pressure, participants also discussed how they would outsource support in college teaching to outside-of-class times (e.g., office hours) and to other people (e.g., tutors). Additionally, some instructors discussed the heavy influence of tests on their pedagogical decisions. In some cases, educators completely avoided technology usage in the regular classroom because technology was not allowed on the exams, indicating that there was a kind of “teaching to the test” in that they were teaching to the test environment. At the same time, other educators reported how essential technology was during class time to help students increase their understanding of mathematical topics. Overall, these patterns created a snapshot of practices for these educators, and future studies could utilize in-depth interviews to better understand why some educators persisted in using evidence-based pedagogical practices and some did not.

In another round of data collection, the project honed in on dual enrollment teaching. One pattern that the researchers observed was that instructors often classified their students as STEM or non-STEM. For dual enrollment classes that ran at a college, this was not surprising as it meant the instructor was catering to student interests. However, many of the dual enrollment instructors were teaching primarily to a high school audience, and they were already classifying students based on their future college majors. Dual enrollment instructors also had differential connotations regarding the purpose of math classes for STEM versus non-STEM students: the discussions were positive for STEM students but some were negative for non-STEM students. Another pattern had to do with instructor perceptions on what made a class a “college-level” one and that was not focused on math content. Instructors reported a range of skills such as students’ problem-solving, independence, responsibility, study habits, and time management. They also described traits of a college course like the quick pace. Combined, these patterns helped the researchers to see how instructors thought of their dual enrollment classes, and future work could consider focus groups with a variety of dual enrollment stakeholders for a more complete picture of the role these courses play.

Lastly, in addition to better understanding this understudied class of math educators, the research team also collaborated with an instructor who incorporated research findings into a graduate-level capstone course for educators to better understand the landscape of teaching in between high school and college institutions. The last phase examined how the students in the course, who were high school educators interested in college teaching, responded to class activities built around the research findings from the earlier phases in the project. The class activities were generally effective in achieving learning goals, and they are posted on the project website to help other teacher educators as well as those running professional development workshops for similar populations.
